story:
iVi. For you?

If you have any of these desires, then iVi is for you.

  • You want to share media wirelessly to multiple devices in a snap
  • You want to be anonymous when downloading files
  • You want to stream data publicly and quickly  
  • You want to communicate offline
  • You want a new internet

The wired-world of the Internet has been rapidly evolving... and growing ephemeral wings. Long gone are the days when networked connectivity is done sitting anchored in place locked to a screen. Connectivity has become wireless and mobile, flexible and multi-functional—free to work and play. The realm of the coffee-shop not the cubicle.

Rising on the edge of this tide of change comes increased complexity. New wireless and smart devices spring up daily. Such that now they outnumber us. All are able to connect, one way or another. However, there remains a missing element. We lack an easy, mobile, cross-functional way to network everything together. Enter iVi, an easy-to-use, go-anywhere device hub, to connect all that cool stuff together.

The Digital Age, dominated by information, is edging out and leading into the Synergy Age. A time when everyone and everything connects, sufficiently. When able to connect more easily and reliably, new opportunities develop. The current term, Internet of Things, describes a connected world full of benefits. iVi—in its most basic form—a portable micro-server connects all those Things, anywhere and everywhere.

Evidence is apparent that networking trends often gain valuable weight. Take the make-it-or-break-it importance that social media networking now wields. Where once it was purely for entertainment—kitty videos and bloopers—now these sites, including YouTube and Twitter, are arenas that big business and academia must enter or be left behind. How we network evolves. Ideas spark trends that eventually become mainstream. New systems, new applications, new opportunities. iVi provides another way to network—the meshnet.

"Meshnet" describes a network topology where all nodes are equal, working together to distribute data across the entire network. A robust, decentralized network where nodes can be eliminated but the mesh survives. Mostly utilized as a military technology, still communities form to cast out meshnets. Hyperboria, a virtual meshnet, operates through the Internet via cjdns encrypted nodes. Techielitist activist groups, the Meshnet Project and The Darknet Plan, exist alongside in commonality. Public meshnet ventures, however, are not as common. The most successful being Guifi.net in Catalonia with over 25,000 working nodes. Locally, initiatives seed a meshnet and piece-by-piece the mesh spreads ending eventually at a globalized, neutral entity. Herein lies the purpose of iVi: to provide an easy-to-use meshnet option to fill-in the gaps faster—but more so—to make meshnet technology accessible to everyone, not just the technical elite.  

Though immature and scattered, meshnets have immediate application. Already, they've been used in emergency response experiments and as low-cost network alternatives. When disaster strikes, either natural or political, meshnets have provided a method to connect independent of the often biased, centralized Net. Tech writers from big titles discuss the mesh. At times, weighing the pros and cons, but more recently giving convincing argument for the implementation of the meshnet. No matter what, the meshnet is here to stay. But what does iVi brings to the meshnet model? iVi is a wireless mesh device that is portable, affordable, but also scalable. A single iVi acts as a wireless media sever, while multiple iVi go on to create meshnets.

Some may argue that the Internet, as the established foundation, is what we must build onto to further inter-connectivity infrastructure. That devices like iVi, that create independent networks, are out-of-this-world. Experts beg to differ. The think tank, Institute for the Future, is calling for ideas to #reinventthenet and so look towards a Second Curve Internet as a way to redesign a way from a broken Internet. iVi is versatile. It can link to and share the traditional Internet, but more importantly, iVi gives us a new design: an adaptable and safe way to connect.


Reasons why experts doubt the future of the old Internet reside alongside issues such as the failure of Net Neutrality, post-Snowden privacy concerns, aging infrastructure, ISPs modifying traffic content, growing bandwidth costs and caps and fragility concerns effected by nature and institutions. Rising criticism of current Net architecture stems even from Neticons. Father of the Web, Tim Berners-Lee, calls for a Magna Carta for the Web. While, Jaron Lanier, VR pioneer and author of Who Owns the Future?, questions the model of the "Siren Server". Basically, its a mess. Just as electric cars like Telsa Model S give viable alternatives to fossil-fuel-bred vehicles, iVi gives an alternative to an elderly information superhighway that continues to wait for the dark-fiber promise of Internet2.  

The dream of a wireless world goes back far. In the 1900s, Nikola Tesla spoke often of his "World-system" of wireless transmission. However, the version of the Internet in operation is rooted more in the "Galactic Network" envisioned by J.C.R. Licklider of MIT, first head of DARPA. But, these two impressions now meld present day and receive further influence from the "cloud" concept brought to us in the 90s. The cloud—storage and computing—describes the increasing ability to access data and apps not from a single computer but the network itself. Meanwhile, the future of the Internet mashes all these concepts together, such that the interconnection of wireless devices eventually becomes the cloud. This is where iVi comes in, as a first-generation device that provides a personal wireless cloud, by meshing with other iVi and peripheral wireless devices. 

iVi connects everything

Most people, when they think of the "cloud", think of IT giants and their armies of servers. Massive banks of computers serving the Web. Giving netizens instant access to endless storage and sophisticated software no matter where they are... well.. as long as they're on a stable and fast line in the realm of the Net. There are as many clouds as there are giants: Amazon, Google, Apple... cumulus. Surprisingly, though, the cloud is a concept that goes beyond the Internet. What the cloud defines is the access of data from any node of a network, whether that network be online or offline. 

Although having the ability to access the online world, iVi can "cloud" in two new ways. Both offline. First, it is a personal cloud in that it makes wireless connections with all your compliant devices to share and stream data over this private network. Second, iVi units can mesh together to form offline networks. On this public network, data can be accessed and shared using a file-sharing system called BitTorrent. More, apps can reach across this offline network. Apps to chat, message board, stream and such. iVi operates on open-source code, so apps are only limited by the imagination and ingenuity of the community to create. 

"Basically, iVi gives you a new cloud, and its all yours. And this cloud is seamless by being wireless, private by being offline, and portable by being a mobile device. All of this so you can enjoy a new level of digital integration." 

Just a few things iVi can do:

  • Share that new cool file with your friends all at the same time.
  • Watch a movie streamed to each of the family's tabs, in a tent, camping.
  • Driving in your car, your iVi mesh picks up and plays outside mp3 collections.
  • Share files anonymously at home then do it again at work or school. 
  • Play that favorite video on all the displays in a room.
  • Stream an educational video to every UPnP device in a classroom of students.
  • Network computers and devices with an offline connection that speeds.
  • Build a offline, off-grid meshnet for a neighborhood, university, town, city or country.

iVi is small, powerful and mobile

With iVi as the nerve center of your personal cloud, you can browse, play, share, store, manage, even edit all your audio, photos, video and documents, from any connected and capable UPnP device. iVi is a small, mobile, wireless, micro-cloud server. It enables seamless, on-demand media browsing and streaming between all your digital devices, in HD.

Where could you use iVi?

  • Keep iVi in your home as an all-round media server for all your wireless devices.
  • Use iVi in your business offline, portable and private data storage and sharing. 
  • Install iVi in your car as a permanent wireless entertainment gateway to on-board sound and displays.
  • Put iVi in your restaurant or coffee shop as a media library for customers.
  • Libraries would love iVi for more than one reason.
  • Teachers might want to stream presentations, images and video clips to student devices and fast-track interactive education.
  • Artists and designers could use iVi to showcase their digital portfolio.
  • Setup a mesh network as a low-cost alternative to the Internet or where the Net has been incapacitated or is just plain absent.
  • Take iVi traveling and see what you can mesh with.
  • Use iVi in a lab to transfer large files wirelessly between workstations.
  • Employees each having an iVi could share data privately offline whenever they cross paths. 

Mesh Network: iVi supports advanced mesh networks for file-sharing between all units in range (see Koch antenna). Forming large, private networks. Suitable for most wireless devices, including computers, smartphones, laptops, tablets, and PSP/NDS. 

                             iVi supports two types of meshnet protocols: B.A.T.M.A.N.-adv and                                  cjdns. The first through software. B.A.T.M.A.N-adv runs on a Layer2                                protocol, and eliminates issues associated with NAT from node to                                    node.The second is implemented via hardware (random number                                      generator) to create IPv6 addresses, thereby off-loading the                                              processing from the AR9331 chipset.                                              

Wi-Fi Hotspot: Instantly turn any connection, wired or wireless, into a high-speed Wi-Fi hotspot. iVi supports Wi-Fi repeater functions and includes an Ethernet port for connection to a wired broadband router.

Cloud Storage: Create your own cloud storage network. Turn a USB storage drive into personal cloud storage for easy file access and media streaming via the included Kodi Media Player or iVi’s built-in web interface. Add more iVi or additional hard drives to increase storage space without any limit.

Compatibility: iVi has multiple internet connection modes and supports a wide range of formats. Also, iVi streams or transcodes most media types with little or no configuration. iVi is powered by MEncoder, FFmpeg, tsMuxeR, AviSynth, MediaInfo, VLC and more.

Security: iVi is secure personal micro-cloud. All local connected devices and data are accessible only to local account holders. iVi also encrypts and decrypts files to be shared or stored in the public cloud. iVi supports guest networks on the 2.4GHz band, enabling you to share internet access with others without granting them access to your private network.

Charge Mobile Devices: iVi runs on its own internal 5000mAh battery, or AC power when using the provided adapter. Smart LEDs display remaining power levels. Three of the USB ports deliver up to one amp of power to charge a peripheral device, and can do this simultaneously when iVi is recharging itself. Furthermore, the                                            internal battery runs 24 hrs on active mode, while standby lasts                                        months without needing a recharge. Notice that then USB solar                                        charger bonus perk makes iVi even more portable.


Game Networks: Create your own private game network with much faster speeds than the internet. Unlimited Folders on PS3 and Xbox.


Share Broadband: 3G, 4G, or LTE wireless broadband connections can be shared with a wireless USB adapter and your cellular service.

Media Streaming: Onboard DLNA media server for streaming music, photos, and video from an attached USB hard drive. iVi also includes the Kodi app, which supports most file formats, including bmp, jpg, and png for photos; mp3, wav, m4a, mp4, mov, and m4v for audio/video.                                                                                                      Live Subtitles on All Devices: If your device does not support a video subtitle format, iVi will add it to the video stream automatically for viewing. If you don't have subtitles at all, UMS will add them for                                  you via the options on your device.

True Motion (Frame Interpolation): iVi smooths video motion for added realism by adding frames to the usual 24 or 25fps using InterFrame, an AviSynth plugin with SVP libraries. 
Automatic Bitrate Adjustment: Automatically changes video bitrate based on your network speed.
H.264 Transcoding: On wireless networks H.264 achieves the same quality as MPEG-2, but with much smaller files.
Overscan Compensation: On televisions with overscan, iVi compensates to show the whole video. Transcoding is accomplished                              via a BCM70015 BGA device, a low-cost, effective method to offload                                 video processing.

Web Interface: An iVi web interface provides added support for devices without DLNA.
Instant Browsing: Browse large file libraries without having to wait for folders to be scanned.

USB & Ethernet Ports:  iVi has three USB ports for connecting and charging drives and peripherals, plus an Ethernet port for connecting to a wired broadband router. iVi recharges away from home by way of an external charging options, such as recharging by our own iViPower LIPO, or by a USB solar panel (check out the perks).


Automatic Plugin Installation: Download and install plugins automatically.

A full-featured, wireless micro-cloud hub. Lithium-polymer battery-powered and UPnP ready. iVi provides high-security, multi-mode network connectivity in a convenient mobile format. Two USB ports for extra drives or peripherals, AC power and charging, round out this first, truly mobile, micro-cloud server.

iVi is a perfect hub for people, groups, families and organizations to defend your information from unauthorized access and manipulation. iVi is the ideal way to assure information security across your private network.

Manufacturers are investing heavily in wireless technology to satisfy the growing need for mobile networking power. Very soon most enterprises will be enjoying the economic benefits of doing business over an advanced wireless network and providing their organizations with new levels of speed and access to all their media.

iVi is on the the leading edge of the the new secure network revolution and you have the opportunity to participate at the the beginning with this emerging technology.

Key Concepts:

  • Personal Cloud: Share or stream stored medial to devices. From iVi, play a movie on your mobile, smart-TV and tab at the same time. Use one device to wirelessly interact with another via iVi. Use your mobile to control your smart-TV through iVi. Connect either by direct wireless and/or UPnP/DLNA.
  • Collaborative Cloud: Assemble shared cloud space by linking to other iVi. Cloud space grows collectively with each iVi. Access files easily and quickly on iVi, which operates on a BitTorrent system using a built-in, real-time-updated, tracker.
  • Long-ranged: 1 kilometer beyond, iVi-to-iVi wireless networks connect. Extended broadcast range due to case-embedded, state-of-the-art fractal, Koch antennas.
  • Cone of Silence:  iVi-to-iVi connectivity operates on Layer 2 protocol, without the use of traceable IP addresses. iVi mesh together through a process akin to that found in socialVPN systems providing privacy and security.
  • Scalable: A single iVi functions as a media server, a few iVi meshed function as a small-world network for a neighborhood, business or university, 10 iVi meshed covers communication and data sharing needs for a small town. Unit-by-unit, build the network you need. Offline and offgrid, if needs be.
  • Nimble: Data transfer rates starting at 150 MB/s. Implements the new Intel® Dual Band Wireless-AC 7260 Wi-Fi and Bluetooth adapter.
  • Flexible: A 5000mAh Li-poly battery allows for one-hour of continual operation (the battery in standby/off keeps its charge for months). Giving iVi portability and a secondary use as a recharging station for other devices. iVi is recharged through the single microUSB port.
  • Versatile: Four USB ports, 3 allow for peripheral device interaction, including but not limited to storage capacity, signal modification and power-charging options, while the fourth is for special programming. iVi comes with a 32GB microUSB thumb drive. The Ethernet port allows iVi to operate as a hard-linked wireless router. But iVi can also act as a wireless hotspot when connected to a wireless broadband connection. iVi grows into multiple uses.
  • Extendible: iVi connected to wired-broadband through the Ethernet port is able to share a user-controlled portion of bandwidth through the iVi meshnet, allowing for connected devices to connect to the traditional Internet. Further, iVi uses miniDLNA to communicate with Private Networks, such as those used with Xbox ad Play-Station.
  • Decentralized: Create small-world networks, or mesh networks by linking any number of iVi together to build your own Public or Private networks for communication and information transfer. Network capabilities grow in relation to local iVi density in a region.
  • Community-driven: Crowdfunding market entry to demonstrate iVi dedication to the community. iVi has been built from open-source inventiveness, such as implementing Linux/openWRT and BitTorrent in its design. Openness will remain a strong focus for iVi.
  • Neutral: The original vision of the Internet was a public forum to share ideas without bias or selectivity. With the failure of Net Neutrality, content selectivity and bias become issues. iVi returns to those neutral roots.
  • Free: iVi is affordable at CAD $99 per unit with a small, one-time service fee if a group of iVi are required to be pre-meshed. However, a user with basic IT skills could do this on their own following the published guidelines. There will be NO further fees beyond this, including no network service fees.

Specifications:

  • Atheros AR7240 CPU (400Mhz)
  • Atheros AR9331 Chipset (integrated wireless)
  • BCM70015 BGA Video processor
  • Hardware implementation: random number generator (update for cjdns/IPv6 encryption)
  • 802.11 b/g/n 150Mbps (130Mbps real) wireless power output 20dBm - 100mW
  • 802.11 ac internal PCIe Intel 7260 802.11ac, Dual Band, 80MHz, 2x2
  • Fractal antenna: dual multi-snowflake Koch, embedded in the plastic case
  • 16 MB flash memory
  • 64 MB RAM
  • Internal High-Speed hub: 4 USB ports, 3 are used for storage and peripheral device interaction (comes with one 32GB thumb-drive)
  • Internal 8GB microSD root ext3/4
  • Powered via internal 5000 mA/h lithium polymer battery 18.5W; active operation 24 hr; standby/off-mode 6 month charge.
  • USB output 5V/1A
  • Normal operation 100 mA with WiFi with external powered WiFi modem 85 mA
  • 1x Gigabit Ethernet port / 4x USB 2.0 port for external drive
  • Serial console on the micro USB connector / charge port (USB serial FDDI)
  • Dimensions: 127*66.5*21 mm
  • Weight: 180g

Project Development:

First two iVi prototypes have been finished including soft steel mold development. The PCB will be changed to include a built-in high speed USB hub and an USB to serial interface. 

Production Timeline:

  • November, 2014: Pilot run and testing with completed revisions. 
  • December, 2014: Final production run and packaging.
  • January, 2015: First iVi units ship to our IndieGoGo EARLY ADOPTERS
  • March, 2015: Full iVi production starts with shipping in April, 2015 

Campaign Messages:

Why we need your help 
We have fully functional samples of iVi that will soon be ready for production. Though we have big ambitions, but we do not have the financial capacity to produce large runs or test the market. 
Spread the word 
Help us by spreading the word via email and social media. You can earn $10 in credit toward our campaign every time one of your referrals purchases a iVi. The amount of credit you can earn is limitless! 
Once the campaign is over, we will apply this credit to your account, giving you a refund on your purchase or credit on the purchase of a new iVi. Please note that contributors cannot receive referral credit for referring themselves. In regards to two contributors: only one can be the 'referrer' and receive campaign credit for the other's contribution. 
How to participate in the referral program: 
It’s simple. 
  1. Log in to your Indiegogo account. Be sure to use the same account you used when you claimed your iVi. 
  2. Then, look below our main video at the top of the story page for buttons to share and copy your unique URL. 
  3. Start sharing!

FAQ

(1) What exactly is a meshnet and how does iVi create them?

A mesh describes an interlaced structure, while a net, or network, describes the inter-connectivity of things. Mesh nets may be wired or wireless, but in the case of iVi, meshnet refers to a wireless mesh net (WMN).

The interlaced connections of a meshnet are wireless access points (WAP) distributed over a location. Each of these wireless points in the meshnet acts as both a host and client. Data sent from one iVi is forwarded across the network until it reaches the destined iVi. The data follows the shortest route, which may change over time. In this way, the meshnet is decentralized, simplified and flexible. Further reading on the subject can be found here.

As reported in Wikipedia on the subject, due to advances in radio technology that has brought down cost, size and power requirements, mesh nodes are able to contain multiple radios for increased modularity, and greater application.

In this way iVi, using B.A.T.M.A.N. advanced routing and an Intel 7260 as the radio, allows multiple iVi nodes to relay traffic seamlessly and securely. Additionally, the USB data pins are connected to a GL850G USB hub Integrated Circuit (IC) running at 12MHz. The whole system is supported by the base software, an open, Linux-based routing platform called openWRT.

For info on Intel 7260, read this and this.

(2) Is there hardware interface for video?

There is no hardware interface. Rather, the video process is hardware implementation that interfaces using web streaming.

The AR9331 (integrated router/processor) off-loads the video processing to BCM70015. The processed video data is then streamed by AR9331 to a UPnP/DLNA device for play-back using a web interface. This pairing of chips has been done because although AR9331 is fast for routing, when used for video streaming it has insufficient processing power to translate files formats.

According the the chip manufacturer, BCM70015 "is the industry's lowest cost, lowest power, highly integrated media processing solution for high definition (HD) video playback applications." It's applications include streaming video over IP.

(3) Would iVi enable me to ditch my web hosting company and have a local server running PHP/MySQL (or whatever else I want)?

The answer to your query: most likely. It really depends on how many users you have. 10,000 hits on your webpage a month or less, iVi could handle (most webpages get around 3000). Unless you're talking about a social networking or commerce site. But blogs or personal pages - no problem. 

So the real answer is basically, yes. iVi can run PHP/MySQL. iVi runs on openWRT, so here are some notes on this type of system.

(4) What's the difference between iVi & MR3040?

So the differences between iVi and the TL-MR3040:

  • iVi includes Intel 7260ac.
  • iVi has a 4 port USB hub (two ports are used one for the BCM70015 video processor, and the other for the Intel 7260).
  • Of the 4 ports, two ports can be used for charging external devices via USB or interacting with peripheral devices like USB hard drives, USB solar panels and charging packs and so on.
  • iVi has a serial connection via the micro-USB charge port.
  • iVi also has a 5000mA/h Li-poly battery. 
  • iVi is also has 5G.

MR3040 has one USB port, no serial interface for development and half the battery power.

(5) I have never used any cloud services because it really freaks me out. The idea of uploading my personal info to the Internet. "Yes", they say it's secure, but what is really “SECURE” these days?

We loved the idea of security. The Product Realization Centre team used Dropbox, Box, and others cloud-based service. But we're concerned that our data could be misused. Our team is spread all over Canada and the world so security is always an issue. Bypassing security issues is one of the creative forces behind iVi.

(6) I see this is a flexible funding campaign. Does that mean you have the means to produce ALL the units "ordered" through this campaign even if you don't meet your goal?

When this campaign started we needed $32K CAD to complete it. However, early into the launch of the campaign, we received outside funding: such that the full build/run has been funded. This is why we changed the goal to $6K CAD.  Because, even if we don't reach the 6K goal, we will still be making a full build run and fill all the orders.

(7) Why not also make this an Open Source Hardware project? 

The iVi project will be open source hardware, once it matures a bit. Lots of work still to do. 

Some projects use indiegogo late in the game: basically as a marketing and sales platform for a product that has been finished. While others use IGG to fund an idea that has no substance so it may gain form and function, However, iVi is middle-of-the-road. We have a couple of prototypes. But changes are still occurring to hardware for the final version. Mostly in response to concerns and requests from the community but partially from sparks of improvement from team discussions. Since the dawn of the campaign, the iVi design has been amended to included additional components, the BCM70015 and a hardware-based RNG, to increase optimal functionality for iVi users. 

That being said, iVi has begun to engage the open source hardware community. We tried to engage the meshnet and torrent communities on reddit, and though we encountered some interest and support quite some of that community cried doubt, scam and fraud. So it occurs when new dogs enter an old arena. Pissing contests. Time we'd rather spend on getting iVi the best it can be, instead of defeating trolls on bridges.  Additionally, we have engaged the PirateBox community. Here, you can see the basic blocks, though we haven't completed the changes to the PCB yet.

As to open source software on GitHub. Yup, that's coming too. We're coding away and will release it in a month or so. So coders and hackers can play.

(8) Will it be possible to install systems like ownCloud, ArkOS and Sandstorm on the iVi?

We are not sure about ArkOS, but Sandstorm there is a strong possibility since the Linux kernel running on iVi is 3.7.9 and Sandstorm requires at least 3.1.3.

ownCloud is based on ARM and AR9331 is based on MIPS. So we are not sure if it can be ported or not.

(9) Can the iVi be used as a VPN for secure internet browsing?

Absolutely, YES. We used an early version of iVi as an openVPN client and with a little configuration iVi can also be used as an openVPN server.

Feel free to ask more questions.
story_txt:
iVi. For you?If you have any of these desires, then iVi is for you.
You want to share media wirelessly to multiple devices in a snap
You want to be anonymous when downloading files
You want to stream data publicly and quickly  
You want to communicate offline
You want a new internet














The wired-world of the Internet has been rapidly evolving... and growing ephemeral wings. Long gone are the days when networked connectivity is done sitting anchored in place locked to a screen. Connectivity has become wireless and mobile, flexible and multi-functional—free to work and play. The realm of the coffee-shop not the cubicle.Rising on the edge of this tide of change comes increased complexity. New wireless and smart devices spring up daily. Such that now they outnumber us. All are able to connect, one way or another. However, there remains a missing element. We lack an easy, mobile, cross-functional way to network everything together. Enter iVi, an easy-to-use, go-anywhere device hub, to connect all that cool stuff together.The Digital Age, dominated by information, is edging out and leading into the Synergy Age. A time when everyone and everything connects, sufficiently. When able to connect more easily and reliably, new opportunities develop. The current term, Internet of Things, describes a connected world full of benefits. iVi—in its most basic form—a portable micro-server connects all those Things, anywhere and everywhere.
Evidence is apparent that networking trends often gain valuable weight. Take the make-it-or-break-it importance that social media networking now wields. Where once it was purely for entertainment—kitty videos and bloopers—now these sites, including YouTube and Twitter, are arenas that big business and academia must enter or be left behind. How we network evolves. Ideas spark trends that eventually become mainstream. New systems, new applications, new opportunities. iVi provides another way to network—the meshnet."Meshnet" describes a network topology where all nodes are equal, working together to distribute data across the entire network. A robust, decentralized network where nodes can be eliminated but the mesh survives. Mostly utilized as a military technology, still communities form to cast out meshnets. Hyperboria, a virtual meshnet, operates through the Internet via cjdns encrypted nodes. Techielitist activist groups, the Meshnet Project and The Darknet Plan, exist alongside in commonality. Public meshnet ventures, however, are not as common. The most successful being Guifi.net in Catalonia with over 25,000 working nodes. Locally, initiatives seed a meshnet and piece-by-piece the mesh spreads ending eventually at a globalized, neutral entity. Herein lies the purpose of iVi: to provide an easy-to-use meshnet option to fill-in the gaps faster—but more so—to make meshnet technology accessible to everyone, not just the technical elite.  Though immature and scattered, meshnets have immediate application. Already, they've been used in emergency response experiments and as low-cost network alternatives. When disaster strikes, either natural or political, meshnets have provided a method to connect independent of the often biased, centralized Net. Tech writers from big titles discuss the mesh. At times, weighing the pros and cons, but more recently giving convincing argument for the implementation of the meshnet. No matter what, the meshnet is here to stay. But what does iVi brings to the meshnet model? iVi is a wireless mesh device that is portable, affordable, but also scalable. A single iVi acts as a wireless media sever, while multiple iVi go on to create meshnets.Some may argue that the Internet, as the established foundation, is what we must build onto to further inter-connectivity infrastructure. That devices like iVi, that create independent networks, are out-of-this-world. Experts beg to differ. The think tank, Institute for the Future, is calling for ideas to #reinventthenet and so look towards a Second Curve Internet as a way to redesign a way from a broken Internet. iVi is versatile. It can link to and share the traditional Internet, but more importantly, iVi gives us a new design: an adaptable and safe way to connect.


Reasons why experts doubt the future of the old Internet reside alongside issues such as the failure of Net Neutrality, post-Snowden privacy concerns, aging infrastructure, ISPs modifying traffic content, growing bandwidth costs and caps and fragility concerns effected by nature and institutions. Rising criticism of current Net architecture stems even from Neticons. Father of the Web, Tim Berners-Lee, calls for a Magna Carta for the Web. While, Jaron Lanier, VR pioneer and author of Who Owns the Future?, questions the model of the "Siren Server". Basically, its a mess. Just as electric cars like Telsa Model S give viable alternatives to fossil-fuel-bred vehicles, iVi gives an alternative to an elderly information superhighway that continues to wait for the dark-fiber promise of Internet2.  The dream of a wireless world goes back far. In the 1900s, Nikola Tesla spoke often of his "World-system" of wireless transmission. However, the version of the Internet in operation is rooted more in the "Galactic Network" envisioned by J.C.R. Licklider of MIT, first head of DARPA. But, these two impressions now meld present day and receive further influence from the "cloud" concept brought to us in the 90s. The cloud—storage and computing—describes the increasing ability to access data and apps not from a single computer but the network itself. Meanwhile, the future of the Internet mashes all these concepts together, such that the interconnection of wireless devices eventually becomes the cloud. This is where iVi comes in, as a first-generation device that provides a personal wireless cloud, by meshing with other iVi and peripheral wireless devices. 

iVi connects everything

Most people, when they think of the "cloud", think of IT giants and their armies of servers. Massive banks of computers serving the Web. Giving netizens instant access to endless storage and sophisticated software no matter where they are... well.. as long as they're on a stable and fast line in the realm of the Net. There are as many clouds as there are giants: Amazon, Google, Apple... cumulus. Surprisingly, though, the cloud is a concept that goes beyond the Internet. What the cloud defines is the access of data from any node of a network, whether that network be online or offline. Although having the ability to access the online world, iVi can "cloud" in two new ways. Both offline. First, it is a personal cloud in that it makes wireless connections with all your compliant devices to share and stream data over this private network. Second, iVi units can mesh together to form offline networks. On this public network, data can be accessed and shared using a file-sharing system called BitTorrent. More, apps can reach across this offline network. Apps to chat, message board, stream and such. iVi operates on open-source code, so apps are only limited by the imagination and ingenuity of the community to create. "Basically, iVi gives you a new cloud, and its all yours. And this cloud is seamless by being wireless, private by being offline, and portable by being a mobile device. All of this so you can enjoy a new level of digital integration." Just a few things iVi can do:
Share that new cool file with your friends all at the same time.
Watch a movie streamed to each of the family's tabs, in a tent, camping.
Driving in your car, your iVi mesh picks up and plays outside mp3 collections.
Share files anonymously at home then do it again at work or school. 
Play that favorite video on all the displays in a room.
Stream an educational video to every UPnP device in a classroom of students.

Network computers and devices with an offline connection that speeds.
Build a offline, off-grid meshnet for a neighborhood, university, town, city or country.

Use iVi in your business offline, portable and private data storage and sharing.

Put iVi in your restaurant or coffee shop as a media library for customers.
Libraries would love iVi for more than one reason.
Teachers might want to stream presentations, images and video clips to student devices and fast-track interactive education.
Artists and designers could use iVi to showcase their digital portfolio.
Setup a mesh network as a low-cost alternative to the Internet or where the Net has been incapacitated or is just plain absent.

Use iVi in a lab to transfer large files wirelessly between workstations.
Employees each having an iVi could share data privately offline whenever they cross paths.

Furthermore, the                                            internal battery runs 24 hrs on active mode, while standby lasts                                        months without needing a recharge. Notice that then USB solar                                        charger bonus perk makes iVi even more portable.

Game Networks: Create your own private game network with much faster speeds than the internet. Unlimited Folders on PS3 and Xbox.

Share Broadband: 3G, 4G, or LTE wireless broadband connections can be shared with a wireless USB adapter and your cellular service.

Media Streaming: Onboard DLNA media server for streaming music, photos, and video from an attached USB hard drive. iVi also includes the Kodi app, which supports most file formats, including bmp, jpg, and png for photos; mp3, wav, m4a, mp4, mov, and m4v for audio/video.                                                                                                      Live Subtitles on All Devices: If your device does not support a video
 subtitle format, iVi will add it to the video stream automatically for 
viewing. If you don't have subtitles at all, UMS will add them for                                  you 
via the options on your device.

True Motion (Frame Interpolation): iVi smooths video motion for added realism by adding frames to the 
usual 24 or 25fps using InterFrame, an AviSynth plugin with SVP 
libraries.  Automatic Bitrate Adjustment: Automatically changes video bitrate based on your network speed.H.264 Transcoding: On wireless networks H.264 achieves the same quality as MPEG-2, but with much smaller files.Overscan Compensation: On televisions with overscan, iVi compensates to show the whole video. Transcoding is accomplished                              via a BCM70015 BGA device, a low-cost, effective method to offload                                 video processing.
Web Interface: An iVi web interface provides added support for devices without DLNA.Instant Browsing: Browse large file libraries without having to wait for folders to be scanned.


USB & Ethernet Ports:  iVi has three USB ports for connecting and charging drives and peripherals, plus an Ethernet port for connecting to a wired broadband router. iVi recharges away from home by way of an external charging options, such as recharging by our own iViPower LIPO, or by a USB solar panel (check out the perks).

Automatic Plugin Installation: Download and install plugins automatically. 

A full-featured, wireless micro-cloud hub. Lithium-polymer battery-powered and UPnP ready. iVi provides high-security, multi-mode network connectivity in a convenient mobile format. Two USB ports for extra drives or peripherals, AC power and charging, round out this first, truly mobile, micro-cloud server.
iVi is a perfect hub for people, groups, families and organizations 
to defend your information from unauthorized access and manipulation. 
iVi is the ideal way to assure information security across your private 
network.
Manufacturers are investing heavily in wireless technology to satisfy the growing need for mobile networking power. Very soon most enterprises will be enjoying the economic benefits of doing business over an advanced wireless network and providing their organizations with new levels of speed and access to all their media.
iVi is on the the leading edge of the the new secure network revolution and you have the opportunity to participate at the the beginning with this emerging technology.


Key Concepts:



Personal Cloud: Share or stream stored medial to devices.
From iVi, play a movie on your mobile, smart-TV and tab at the same time. Use
one device to wirelessly interact with another via iVi. Use your mobile to
control your smart-TV through iVi. Connect either by direct wireless and/or
UPnP/DLNA.


Collaborative Cloud: Assemble shared cloud space by linking
to other iVi. Cloud space grows collectively with each iVi. Access files easily
and quickly on iVi, which operates on a BitTorrent system using a built-in,
real-time-updated, tracker.


Long-ranged: 1 kilometer beyond, iVi-to-iVi wireless
networks connect. Extended broadcast range due to case-embedded,
state-of-the-art fractal, Koch antennas.


Cone of Silence:  iVi-to-iVi connectivity operates on Layer 2 protocol, without the use of traceable IP addresses. iVi mesh together through a process akin to that found in socialVPN systems providing privacy and security.

Scalable: A single iVi functions as a media server, a few iVi meshed function as a small-world network for a neighborhood, business or university, 10 iVi meshed covers communication and data sharing needs for a small town. Unit-by-unit, build the network you need. Offline and offgrid, if needs be.


Nimble: Data transfer rates starting at 150 MB/s. Implements
the new Intel® Dual Band Wireless-AC 7260 Wi-Fi and Bluetooth adapter.

Flexible: A 5000mAh Li-poly battery allows for one-hour of
continual operation (the battery in standby/off keeps its charge for months). Giving iVi portability and a secondary use as a recharging
station for other devices. iVi is recharged through the single microUSB port.


Versatile: Four USB ports, 3 allow for peripheral device
interaction, including but not limited to storage capacity, signal modification
and power-charging options, while the fourth is for special programming. iVi comes with a 32GB microUSB thumb drive. The
Ethernet port allows iVi to operate as a hard-linked wireless router. But iVi
can also act as a wireless hotspot when connected to a wireless broadband
connection. iVi grows into multiple uses.

Extendible: iVi connected to wired-broadband through the
Ethernet port is able to share a user-controlled portion of bandwidth through the
iVi meshnet, allowing for connected devices to connect to the traditional
Internet. Further, iVi uses miniDLNA to communicate with Private Networks, such
as those used with Xbox ad Play-Station.


Decentralized: Create small-world networks, or mesh networks
by linking any number of iVi together to build your own Public or Private
networks for communication and information transfer. Network capabilities grow
in relation to local iVi density in a region.


Community-driven: Crowdfunding market entry to demonstrate
iVi dedication to the community. iVi has been built from open-source
inventiveness, such as implementing Linux/openWRT and BitTorrent in its design.
Openness will remain a strong focus for iVi.


Neutral: The original vision of the Internet was a public
forum to share ideas without bias or selectivity. With the failure of Net
Neutrality, content selectivity and bias become issues. iVi returns to those neutral roots.


Free: iVi is affordable at CAD $99 per unit with a small, one-time service fee if a group of iVi are required to be pre-meshed.
However, a user with basic IT skills could do this on their own following the
published guidelines. There will be NO further fees beyond this, including no
network service fees.




Specifications:

Atheros AR7240 CPU (400Mhz)
Atheros AR9331 Chipset (integrated wireless)
BCM70015 BGA Video processor 

Hardware implementation: random number generator (update for cjdns/IPv6 encryption)

802.11 b/g/n 150Mbps (130Mbps real) wireless power output 20dBm - 100mW 
802.11 ac internal PCIe Intel 7260 802.11ac, Dual Band, 80MHz, 2x2
Fractal antenna: dual multi-snowflake Koch, embedded in the plastic case 

16 MB flash memory 
64 MB RAM 
Internal High-Speed hub: 4 USB ports, 3 are used for storage and peripheral device interaction (comes with one 32GB thumb-drive)
Internal 8GB microSD root ext3/4 
Powered via internal 5000 mA/h lithium polymer battery 18.5W; active operation 24 hr; standby/off-mode 6 month charge.
USB output 5V/1A
Normal operation 100 mA with WiFi with external powered WiFi modem 85 mA
1x Gigabit Ethernet port / 4x USB 2.0 port for external drive 
Serial console on the micro USB connector / charge port (USB serial FDDI) 
Dimensions: 127*66.5*21 mm 
Weight: 180g

Project Development:First two iVi prototypes have been finished including soft steel mold development. The PCB will be changed to include a built-in high speed USB hub and an USB to serial interface. 
Production Timeline:
November, 2014: Pilot run and testing with completed revisions. 
December, 2014: Final production run and packaging.
January, 2015: First iVi units ship to our IndieGoGo EARLY ADOPTERS

March, 2015: Full iVi production starts with shipping in April, 2015 

Campaign Messages:Why we need your help We have fully functional samples of iVi that will soon be ready for production. Though we have big ambitions, but we do not have the financial capacity to produce large runs or test the market. Spread the word 
Help us by spreading the word via email and social media. You can earn $10 in credit toward our campaign every time one of your referrals purchases a iVi.  The amount of credit you can earn is limitless! 
Once the campaign is over, we will apply this credit to your account, giving you a refund on your purchase or credit on the purchase of a new iVi.  Please note that contributors cannot receive referral credit for referring themselves.  In regards to two contributors: only one can be the 'referrer' and receive campaign credit for the other's contribution. How to participate in the referral program: It’s simple. 
Log in to your Indiegogo account. Be sure to use the same account you used when you claimed your iVi. 
Then, look below our main video at the top of the story page for buttons to share and copy your unique URL. 

Start sharing!

FAQ
(1) What exactly is a meshnet and how does iVi create them?
A mesh describes an interlaced structure, while a net, or network, describes the inter-connectivity of things. Mesh nets may be wired or wireless, but in the case of iVi, meshnet refers to a wireless mesh net (WMN).
The interlaced connections of a meshnet are wireless access points (WAP) distributed over a location. Each of these wireless points in the meshnet acts as both a host and client. Data sent from one iVi is forwarded across the network until it reaches the destined iVi. The data follows the shortest route, which may change over time. In this way, the meshnet is decentralized, simplified and flexible. Further reading on the subject can be found here.
As reported in Wikipedia on the subject, due to advances in radio technology that has brought down cost, size and power requirements, mesh nodes are able to contain multiple radios for increased modularity, and greater application.
In this way iVi, using B.A.T.M.A.N. advanced routing and an Intel 7260 as the radio, allows multiple iVi nodes to relay traffic seamlessly and securely. Additionally, the USB data pins are connected to a GL850G USB hub Integrated Circuit (IC) running at 12MHz. The whole system is supported by the base software, an open, Linux-based routing platform called openWRT.
For info on Intel 7260, read this and this.
(2) Is there hardware interface for video?
There is no hardware interface. Rather, the video process is hardware implementation that interfaces using web streaming.
The AR9331 (integrated router/processor) off-loads the video processing to BCM70015. The processed video data is then streamed by AR9331 to a UPnP/DLNA device for play-back using a web interface. This pairing of chips has been done because although AR9331 is fast for routing, when used for video streaming it has insufficient processing power to translate files formats.
According the the chip manufacturer, BCM70015 "is the industry's lowest cost, lowest power, highly integrated media processing solution for high definition (HD) video 
playback applications." It's applications include streaming video over IP.(3) Would iVi enable me to ditch my web hosting company and have a local server running PHP/MySQL (or whatever else I want)?The answer to your query: most likely. It really depends on how many users you have. 10,000 hits on your webpage a month or less, iVi could handle (most webpages get around 3000). Unless you're talking about a social networking or commerce site. But blogs or personal pages - no problem. So the real answer is basically, yes. iVi can run PHP/MySQL. iVi runs on openWRT, so here are some notes on this type of system.(4) What's the difference between iVi & MR3040?So the differences between iVi and the TL-MR3040:
iVi includes Intel 7260ac.
iVi has a 4 port USB hub (two ports are used one for the BCM70015 video processor, and the other for the Intel 7260).
Of the 4 ports, two ports can be used for charging external devices via USB or interacting with peripheral devices like USB hard drives, USB solar panels and charging packs and so on.
iVi has a serial connection via the micro-USB charge port.
iVi also has a 5000mA/h Li-poly battery. 
iVi is also has 5G.

MR3040 has one USB port, no serial interface for development and half the battery power.(5) I have never used any cloud services because it really freaks me out. The idea of uploading my personal info to the Internet. "Yes", they say it's secure, but what is really “SECURE” these days?We loved the idea of security. The Product Realization Centre team used Dropbox, Box, and others cloud-based service. But we're concerned that our data could be misused. Our team is spread all over Canada and the world so security is always an issue. Bypassing security issues is one of the creative forces behind iVi.(6) I see this is a flexible funding campaign. Does that mean you have the means to produce ALL the units "ordered" through this campaign even if you don't meet your goal?When this campaign started we needed $32K CAD to complete it. However, early into the launch of the campaign, we received outside funding: such that the full build/run has been funded. This is why we changed the goal to $6K CAD.  Because, even if we don't reach the 6K goal, we will still be making a full build run and fill all the orders.(7) Why not also make this an Open Source Hardware project? The iVi project will be open source hardware, once it matures a bit. Lots of work still to do. Some projects use indiegogo late in the game: basically as a marketing and sales platform for a product that has been finished. While others use IGG to fund an idea that has no substance so it may gain form and function, However, iVi is middle-of-the-road. We have a couple of prototypes. But changes are still occurring to hardware for the final version. Mostly in response to concerns and requests from the community but partially from sparks of improvement from team discussions. Since the dawn of the campaign, the iVi design has been amended to included additional components, the BCM70015 and a hardware-based RNG, to increase optimal functionality for iVi users. That being said, iVi has begun to engage the open source hardware community. We tried to engage the meshnet and torrent communities on reddit, and though we encountered some interest and support quite some of that community cried doubt, scam and fraud. So it occurs when new dogs enter an old arena. Pissing contests. Time we'd rather spend on getting iVi the best it can be, instead of defeating trolls on bridges.  Additionally, we have engaged the PirateBox community. Here, you can see the basic blocks, though we haven't completed the changes to the PCB yet.As to open source software on GitHub. Yup, that's coming too. We're coding away and will release it in a month or so. So coders and hackers can play.(8) Will it be possible to install systems like ownCloud, ArkOS and Sandstorm on the iVi?We are not sure about ArkOS, but Sandstorm there is a strong possibility since the Linux kernel running on iVi is 3.7.9 and Sandstorm requires at least 3.1.3.ownCloud is based on ARM and AR9331 is based on MIPS. So we are not sure if it can be ported or not.(9) Can the iVi be used as a VPN for secure internet browsing?Absolutely, YES. We used an early version of iVi as an openVPN client and with a little configuration iVi can also be used as an openVPN server.
Feel free to ask more questions.

story:
For everyone who missed the first campaign, we just launched our new version - the LumiPocket! Come see it on our new Campaign!


Please help us take DIY 3D Printing mobile! Support the first portable, open source photo-initiated polymer resin based 3D printing system!

Featured on

You can also check the latest updates on Our Blog or on Our Facebook page, where you 'll be able to follow this project after the campaign.

What is the LumiFold?


It is probably the smallest (measuring just 250 x 120 x 30mm when folded) that you can really travel with, and you still have a building area of 90 x 90 x 90mm.

This printer is the best choice as your first 3d printer! It’s not expensive, and it one of most easy to use printer on the market.

Note: the electronic board on the side was still the prototype stage, the final version is thinner and has a protective enclosure

How it works

In the current stage, a projector is used to project, layer by layer, thin slices of a 3d object on a moving platform inside a vat containing a light-curing resin.
The 3d object is created inside the vat and is then extracted.
An overhead unit, with a laser scanning mechanism, is under design and wil remove the necessity of having a projector.

The story of the LumiFold

It was first designed when a customer asked for a small, portable 3D printer that he wanted ot use for printing dentals molds. He wanted the printer to be cheap and easy to use too. We started developing the LumiFold, and after some months of designing, building prototypes, going back to design again we came up with the current design of the LumiFold. And it proved to be so good, we decided to launch a crowfounding camping to provide everyone interested a cheap, portable and easy to use 3d printer!


Special Update:

We received many questions about the portability of a system that still needs an external projector.

But...

We already had a solution! This accessory was scheduled to launch after the initial campaign, together with the scanner unit. But since we received so many interest on this feature, we are announcing it now:

The Overhead Unit

A laser scanning unit that, unlike other similar setup on other 3D printers, uses steppers and mirrors to quickly scan the area with an UV curing laser.

Price and availability

The overhead unit is still under testing right now. It will attach to every LumiFold you have already bought, and the price will be half the cost of a good projector. It will be available Q1 2014.

We are adding a new perk: "The overhead supporter". You will be able to contribute to the development of the Overhead Unit, and will be one of the first to get it when it will go into production, and you will also get a personal coupon to get 25% off the full price of the Overhead Unit.

More details coming soon...


Special Features


The Stanford bunny, 0.1mm layer thickness
  • The smallest Foldable 3d printer!
  • Low Cost 3D printer, costs half of many 3d printers on the market, and it’s portable!
  • Based on standard/cheap 20x20mm aluminum extrusion
  • Easy to use: just unfold, place under a projector, and print!
  • Low energy consumption (approx. 5W)
  • Interchangeable resin bed and platform, including a smaller one for experimenting and printing small parts
  • Max Print volume 90 x 90 x ~90 mm
  • Z resolution up to 0,01mm!
  • The first 3D printer with a 3D Holographic visualization of the printing progress!
  • Laser Scanner Platform kit available, will transform the LumiFold in a 3D Scanner
  • Travel kit with Lithium battery, with the IPad / IPhone control Kit you are ready for printing everywhere in the world!

Special features: integrated UV sensor

You can use almost every projector with this light curing 3D printer. With many other DLP-based printers on the market, however, you have to do many test with before you can find the exact layer time, since every projector emits a different amount of UV light, that is what cures the resin.

With LumiFold, an integrated UV sensor measures the exact UV light level of your projector and automatically adjusts the layer time. Less time experimenting means less time wasting you precious light–curing resin, and this is isn’t bad, isn’t it?

Special features: flexibility and low-cost design oriented

The LumiFold also has interchangeable building platforms with an engraved grid, so you can also automatically adjust the projection for an accurate and correct size of your 3d printed parts.

Unlike other DLP printers, the LumiFold places the projector over the printer: this lets you use almost every container as resin basin, you don’t need expensive UV-transparent glass or Plexiglas, and you don’t have to apply many coats of anti sticking coating to avoid the container become unusable after a few prints.
For the first tests, we even use small plastic coffee cups! And this was perfect for building small parts and using small amounts of resin, and also keeps the printer costs down.


What you'll also love: every part of the Lumifold has been carefully designed, tested and re-designed until it worked as we initially thought: from the magnetic closure system, to the UV sensor for calibrating the printer to your projector.

What you will get in the box...

An open source  program for slicing and printing has been developed by us and is provided with the printer.
It is Pc compatible, we will also release a Mac version. In the first quarter of 2014, we will expand the compatibility to iPhone and iPad too.

At the same time, the following kits /parts will be available:

  • 3D Laser scanning kit
  • Travel kit with lithium battery and iPad / iPhone control kit


Available Accessories

HoloDock: 3d holographic visualization of 3d parts, or when connected to the LumiFold , shows layer printing progress.

Protective Plexiglas, UV opaque, Fluo Box for shielding the LumiFold from external light when printing.

Travel bag for the interchangeable trays, platforms and power supply.


The HoloDock

This printer is also the first one that has a 3D holographic display that is showing the printing progress. Yes, a real Holographic display! It is called HoloDock, and uses a clever reimagining of the Pepper’s Ghost to create the impression of a real 3D volumetric image of the object you are printing.


It can also be used alone to visualize 3d objects, or you can just take with you the LumiFold 3D printer and leave the HoloDock display at home for maximum portability.

When used with the LumiFold, the image is genereated from the same projector that is used to cure the resin. It can also be used alone, in that case we offer different configurations to use it as 3d object visualizer.

The HoloDock Small can be used with a PC and any monitor, projector, or with your IPhone with the app that is provided.

The HoloDock Bigcan be used with a PC and any monitor, projector, or with your IPad with the provided app.
 

Why IndieGoGo?

Our goal on IndieGoGo is to get the LumiFold into the hands of early adopters like you as soon as possible. We want you to be involved, whether to provide feedback on the experience, and we’ll be hard at work too, delivering updates and new functionality on a regular basis to add more performance and capabilities to the LumiFold.

High level overview of our production plan.

A special thank you for supporting the LumiFold

We appreciate your support, and we are excited to have you join us in our mission to make 3d printing portable!
In the media page of this campaign you will find much more details, photos and videos of the LumiFold and HoloDock. Many more will be uploaded in the following days, so check this page often for updates!



Update: technical details and other questions



Q: Which resin do you use?
A: we are currently using Spot-A materials, Spot GP. It works well and layer curing time is approx. 10 seconds on our Acer x1260 projector. We are currently evaluating other brands.
Q: what is xy resolution?
A: it is related to projector resolution and distance to the tray.
With a 1024x768 projector approx 30cm over the tray the resolution is ~0.2mm and can be increased by using an higher resolution projector, or with a shorter distance.
Q: what is provided, and what should I need?
A: You need to have one projector, a Pc with Usb ports, and UV curing resin.
Q: What are shipping costs?
A: Shipping options for each customer will be comunicated soon before shipping.
You will be able to choose the shipping option you like. If there will be import taxes, we will help you understanding how much they will cost you.

Update: 3d visualization, and full video of the LumiFold from unfolding to printing available now!



The LumiFold, 3d visualization

Update: technical details and other questions

We are currently evaluating other brands.Q: what is xy resolution?A: it is related to projector resolution and distance to the tray.With a 1024x768 projector approx 30cm over the tray the resolution is ~0.2mm and can be increased by using an higher resolution projector, or with a shorter distance.Q: what is provided, and what should I need?A: You need to have one projector, a Pc with Usb ports, and UV curing resin.Q: What are shipping costs?A: Shipping options for each customer will be comunicated soon before shipping.You will be able to choose the shipping option you like. If there will be import taxes, we will help you understanding how much they will cost you.Update: 3d visualization, and full video of the LumiFold from unfolding to printing available now!

The LumiFold, 3d visualization

story:
VoCore2 is an open-sourced smart router runs OpenWrt/LEDE based on Linux, target to make wireless life easier.

It has 300Mbps WIFI, ETHERNET, USB 2.0 Host, UART, SD, SPI, I2C, 40+ GPIOs but size is only one square inch(25.4mm). You can use it as a portable router or write code for it in C, Java, Python, Ruby, Javascript and more. It has various of docks and thousands of softwares to enhance its functions.

VIDEO TUTORIALS:

1. Setup Development Environment

 

 

For beginners, you can use it as a portable router and discovery its fun step by step.

For advanced makers, you can simply setup it for wireless speaker, wireless camera and make a lot of wireless things.

For skilled geeks, you can write code and control inside its core, make your own gadgets.

For expert users, you can mount it into your project freely, boost your product.

For hackers, it is a powerful tool to debug or sniffing wireless networks.

Still think it is hard to use? Check our youtube channel later, every tutorial in video, follow its steps, much easier than read a book :)

We will public our video tutorials, all open source, include:

1. Control LED
2. Light Sensor
3. Temperature Sensor
4. VPN Router(OpenVPN/Tor)
5. File Share Server
6. MP3 Player
7. Wireless Camera
8. Remote Digit Camera Control
9. Wireless Printer
10. DOSBOX "GameBoy" for old dos games with SPI screen
11. Digital Photo Frame
12. Remote control robot/toycar

Already on youtube:

1. PPPoE, use VoCore2 as a normal wireless router
2. use VoCore2 play music(airplay)

For a geek, we should use it like this :)

PS: after around 20seconds, you will find VoCore2 on your computer wireless list :)

 

You will not only get the VoCore but also its full hardware design including schematic, circuit diagram(PCB); full source code including bootloader, system, applications. You are able to control EVERY BIT of your VoCore.

 

 

This is for beginner or the people just want to use it as a wireless router. You do not need any hardware skill, a few clicks on the web interface from your computer/mobile browser, the wireless music/camera/file share will be ready, just like magic.

It exports VoCore2's microSD port, ethernet port and USB2.0 port, and has four channels of AD converter and one channel of DA converter able to connect to various of sensors, we also added an onboard driver-free serial port to USB for the developers.

For me, I use one as a file server to share pictures&videos with my family; one connect to a webcam, to keep secure the door and windows; one plug into a microphone, voice control my smart household appliances; and now I am using it as a VPN router secure me across The Great Firewall and write down words in indiegogo and facebook. :)

It is powered by a microUSB phone charger, no need any special skill everybody can use it. Benefit to its low power consume, even a small power bank(9800mAh) is able to support it work over four days.

Ultimate Version include a shell.

 

 

The Ultimate dock is still too big for you? This one is even smaller. We designed it specially for music. The music transfer though WiFi is 100% pure without any noise, much better than bluetooth.

It is designed to connect to the device support DLNA or Airplay protocol.

 

This one is for the geeks develop internet of things, only 25.4 x 25.4 x 2.8mm, easy to assemble on any PCB board. It is small but complete, runs Linux, and able to code in python/ruby/nodejs/javascript/... directly, super easy.

PS: in fact, you can not feel how small it is until you hold it in your hand :)

 

Our new family member. It is not that powerful as VoCore2 but it has a low price, good for students study and use it for experiment. With castle holes(half-hole) at border it is easy to mount on your customized board.

Note: one account limited to get two, we will not refund postage if you get more.

 

Please visit our store at vocore.io, or blog at vonger.cn, facebook or our former version indiegogo project page, you will find the full story of VoCore and its docks.

 

Thank you for your time and have a nice day. :)

story:
The Air Quad is the ultimate 4-in-1 MFi certified wireless charging station for all Apple family devices, including the iPhone, Apple Watch, AirPods, and iPad.

The Air Trio is a 3-in-1 MFi certified wireless charging station (the ‘lite version’) for those who don’t need to charge AirPods.

*Package includes Air Quad/Trio only. iPhone, Apple Watch, AirPods, iPad are not included.

 

George Buhnici: The "hottest" office wireless charger -- PITAKA AIR QUAD 

Flossy Carter: This is the Ultimate Apple Wireless Charging Station.

iMore: "Wirelessly charge all of your Apple gear with this AirPower alternative."

Cult of Mac: "Air Quad, bringing the family of Apple together for charging, will help you get over AirPower."

TurboFuture:  "100% recommend if you are an Apple fan." 

KnowTechie:  "One simple place to charge all your Apple devices without having to worry about messy charging cables."

The Gadgeteer: "Air Trio or Air Quad solves the long-existing charging issue for Apple users." 

Phone Dog: The best Apple AirPower alternative is the Pitaka Air Trio and Air Quad.

Phone Dog: Best Apple AirPower Alternative

Reviewed by Flossy Carter:

 

We love everything about Apple, so we always get the combo deals they offer, meaning that we own the iPhone and at least one other device such as the Apple Watch, AirPods, an iPad or perhaps all of them. This then gives us a real headache when it comes to working out how to charge everything at once!

You probably have a limited number of sockets, which means that you are forced to charge different devices in different places around your house.

 

It can be chaos on your table

 

Some cables are not compatible with your device

 

Apple tried to build a better charging platform before, but they failed, dramatically.

 

So, if you can’t get a good charger from Apple, what do you do? Do a search for “all-in-one wireless charger” and you will find quite a few out there. However, they all have similar problems, 1) they are not reliable, 2) they do not charge all of your devices and 3) they look cheap and plasticky.

 

For all those Apple family users, we decided to create the ultimate 4-in-1 wireless charger, the only charger you will need.

 

MFi Certified 4-in-1 Wireless Charger for All Apple Devices & Qi Certification

 

We care about our Apple devices, just like you. 

 

Incorrectly charging your devices can cause long term damage to its battery life. This is why we designed our wireless chargers in a very specific way. The MFi & Qi certification means that all the electronics are designed and specifically tuned for apple devices. This ensures that you are charging in a safe manner, exactly the same as your Apple original charger.

 

Drop and Charge

 

Charging has never been so EASY!

 

As the world's first chain-coil wireless charger, both the Air quad and the Air Trio have high-power wireless charging transmitter chain-coils built within the deck zone, which means you can simply drop your Qi-supported device and it starts charging at up to 10W speed. Life is simple, never again do you need to go looking for the charging spot with a so-called wireless charger.

 

Your Life is Free. Don't Be Limited by Devices

 

Charge your Apple Watch any way you like

 

Licensed by Apple, the Apple Watch charging module can either flip up or down with a simple click. This allows you to charge your Apple Watch safely horizontally, or vertically when you use it as a night clock.

 

18W Super Fast Charging Port

 

Charge your phone up to 50% within 30 minutes

 

Both support 18W fast charging and can charge your phone to up to 50% within 30 mins. Saving you time for the more important things in life instead of waiting for your device to be charged.

Case Friendly Design

 

Designed with an adjustable controller, the lightning/type c terminal can be adjusted to fit your device charging no matter whether it wears a case on or not.

Technology Should Serve Human, LDR Design Ensures Your Nice Sleep 

 

We know you may charge your devices in your bedroom as you go to sleep. With the LDR (light-dependent resistor) sensor, the light goes dark automatically when lights off, so that you can sleep peacefully.

 

Using Whilst Charging

 

The Air Quad is also equipped with a foldable stand, helping you to charge devices upright. So you can keep an eye on incoming messages, weather alerts, scores or what’s playing on Spotify. You can also use it for hands-free FaceTime calls or for watching live videos on Facebook and Instagram.

Space-Saving Foldable Design

 

When there is no need for you to charge the iPad or other devices on the terminal, you can always decide to fold it and save space.

Living Organized to Be Successful

 

Organize All Your Apple Devices with A Compact Design

 

Being the ultimate 4-in-1 wireless charging station, the Air Quad charges your iPhone, iPad, AirPods and Apple Watch in one small, simple place and keeps them neat and tidy. Say goodbye to messy cables. Never again will you need to look for your charging cables, now you can live organized.

 

Never Settle for Average, We Always Go for Top-Tier Materials.

 

Built with the premium material combo of aramid fiber & chrome-plated zinc. Both the Air Quad and the Air Trio are designed to be luxurious. The precisely cut aramid fiber face provides an unforgettable, luxurious and sexy smooth touch. The zinc alloy frame provides stability and a high degree of accuracy. Both materials are engineered to dissipate heat effectively whilst still giving that high-end appearance.

 

 

How to use Air Quad & Air Trio:

 

 

Air Quad & Air Trio Voltage Test:

 

 

 

Adapters Available in CN, US, AU, EU, UK types.

story:
Any inquires please contact info@livermoriumltd.co.uk 

=============================================

We started to ship on 31st Jan 2018, here is the first review of the production unit from one of our backers. 

Media Coverage

"People are in love with this keyboard. It is the most funded project [in Motorola's Transform the Smartphone Challenge], in fact." -- Motorola Fans, Felipe Berhau
"...the accessory that makes me go back to the Moto Z" -- 9 to 5 Google, Justin Duino
"...reminiscent of the old DROID phones... or the old HTC Tilt phones." -- phonedog, Alex Wagner 
"the 'old school' feel of having a personal digital assistant (PDA) again." -- Android Community, John Hoff
"An Indiegogo Moto Mod wants to bring back the physical keyboard in a big way" -- Digital Trends, Adam Ismail
"Oh, snap! It's like the Tilt 3 that never was... I'd rock this." -- Taylor Martin (@caspertek), writer for CNET
 

Product Introduction

 

The landscape QWERTY physical keyboard disappeared from the smartphone market almost five years ago. No high-end landscape slider has been manufactured since 2012.

Many messaging users, tech enthusiasts, hackers, researchers, developers, and IT professionals have been longing for a successor.

With the Keyboard Mod, the wait is now over.

 

The Device (Updated with Prototype Images and Video)

The Keyboard Mod features a 5-row landscape QWERTY keyboard that slides out and tilts between 0 and 45 degrees. We’re also considering including a battery to extend the phone’s battery life.* With the Keyboard Mod, your Moto Z transforms into a productive mini PC!

 

Keyboard Layout

We've carefully designed the keyboard layout to maximize productivity and convenience for a variety of users. The Keyboard Mod features:

  • A separate number row
  • Larger common keys
  • Android navigation buttons 
  • Almost all commonly used symbols
  • Arrow keys
  • Custom keys
  • Shortcuts for different utilities

The non-QWERTY layout will be manufactured after we ship the initial QWERTY layout.

For AZERTY, QWERTZ and Scandic Layout users, please refer to the Non-QWERTY layout perks.

Update July 2017: Due to the low demand of AZERTY and Scandic layout, only QWERTZ in black will be produced.

 

Keyboard Characteristics

We care about the comfort of your typing experience. As such, we designed a keyboard with:

  • Extra key travel
  • LED backlight
  • Curved surfaces

We'll perform a variety of tests under different scenarios to make sure the Keyboard Mod delivers the best typing experience. The individual keys are designed to handle more than 200,000 presses without issues.

 

Sliding Mechanism

We're using Teflon™ coating for the sliding track, which ensures a smooth and durable mechanism. 

The sliding frame is designed to provide 100,000 complete slides during its lifespan.

Above is our very first prototype sliding mechanism, with the hinges installed. It will be used in our first demo device.

Today, we're working with Motorola to improve the overall structural design. We'll share more details once everything is 100% confirmed.

Update: We have already made the first prototype. More pictures attached below.

Update 2: We have improved the slider by adding a few more strings on each side.

Colours

We offer 3 colours to match your phone: Black, White and Gold. Black will be the only option for the super early bird perk, and all three colours will be available for the early bird perk. *

Don't think 3 colours are enough? We'll have a special edition that will only be available on Indiegogo, and won't be manufactured again - the "Livermorium Starter Edition"

We're aware of the importance of having a physical keyboard on our phones. And so do you. By purchasing the Limited Edition, you'll show your support and own a "once in a life-time" product, which will never be available again after this campaign.

*If a colour's demand is below the minimum quantity required for manufacturing, a black device will be shipped instead.

Update July 2017: Colour option will be only available for QWERTY layout at the moment. 

 

Development Progress and Timeline

For product development, Livermorium teamed up with top-level engineers and designers. You'll find our team details below.

So far we've finished the model design and verified all technical aspects. We've also validated the structural design using simulation software, and worked with our component supplier for feasibility analysis. Here are some images of the model design work we've been doing.

 

The next step is to build a prototype with the enclosure and the sliding mechanism. We can't use the Moto MDK since we can't add moving parts. We're in discussions with Motorola to get the key documents and components required -- such as the metal connectors and magnetic parts -- in order to build a real working sample. We're planning to be finished prototyping later this month (March), and we'll share results and progress here on a regular basis! (Update: We have build our first prototype! Pictures are shown below)

Then comes the tooling stage. We need your support to fund the best molds and tooling for the enclosure, keyboard, and sliding frame. A sliding keyboard has many more moving parts and is far more complicated than an ordinary "one piece" device. We need your financial support to make sure that the product is not compromised.

Update July 2017:

- The tooling is set to be finished by mid-July

- DVT samples estimated to be made in the week of 17th July

- MP and shipping will start at August

When the tooling is finished, we will build testing samples to verify that everything works as it should, and we'll apply for various certifications -- such as FCC, CE, RoHS, and UL -- to provide a safe device that's legal to sell. This also requires your financial support.

Finally we'll use the funds to reserve the essential material and components needed to build quality devices, and get them assembled in one of Foxconn's factories. We will also need your support to pay for the production line and labour, as well as quality control.

We'll do our absolute best to deliver the Keyboard Mod in the July/August timeframe! 

Here is some pictures of the very first engineering prototype. Please note that merely an engineering sample and improvements will continue to be made, such as a better finish.

 

Cost Summary

Building a physical sliding keyboard involves a lot of engineering and slightly higher upfront cost, since it requires more moving parts and uses a more complex design than other products. To sum things up, funds will be used:

  • To buy the best molds and tooling for the enclosure, slider frame, and keyboard.
  • To passing various certifications and safety tests.
  • To buy materials and components for the device.
  • To rent the assembly line and pay for labour and quality control.
  • For a few other items, such as taxes, material handling and transportation, etc...
